text: mount kelud eruptions sent ash and
gravels 17 kilometers into the
atmosphere when most people were
sleeping they woke up to see their homes
and streets blanketed with thick layers
of ash and the air filled with dust the
authorities raised its alert to the
highest level just one hour before the
eruptions giving people very little time
to move to safety
we're leaving because the status is on
high alert so we've been urged to
evacuate from our village this is the
Jogjakarta airport 300 kilometers away
from on kelud the authorities were
forced to close the airport as volcanic
ash covered the tarmac and runway
blocking visibility and threatening to
damage the aircraft engines a brief
downpour washed away some of the ash but
left the tarmac muddy and slippery at
least three other major airports were
also shut down in cities and villages
across Central and East Java the
authorities are calling for volunteers
to help clear the streets of the debris
Indonesians are resilient in the face of
natural disasters which happened all too
often many people are already out
sweeping the streets and cleaning the
roofs
despite the dusty air the authorities
said the volcanic activities had
decreased and more major eruptions were
unlikely but residents closest to the
crater are still kept away as a
precaution it is unclear how long they
have to stay in the shelters and when
they're allowed to go many may not find
their home the same way they left it
allas Buddhist a trio BBC news Jakarta
